experience: You and Douglas both know Abe Pralle, Leah Shanker, and 6 others
You both worked at Northern Arizona University
You both worked at Northern Arizona University from Sep 2007 to May 2009
Grant and Research Administration Product Development Lead
Product Development Lead for KualiCo's Research Administration, Kuali Coeus.

At the Kuali Foundation I am a Lead Developer on the Kuali Coeus(KC) team. KC is an open source Java based web-application that assists educational institutions in applying for and managing grants and other related projects. It is built with Kuali Rice, Spring, OJB, JSP and Javascript. As the Lead Developer I am responsible for leading new development with 1-2 other developers, being a technical resource for other members of the team and doing general development on the project.

While at the University of Arizona I primarily was assigned to work on Kuali Coeus(KC) a Kuali Foundation software project building open source software to assist educational insitutions apply for and manage grants and other related projects. KC is a web based Java application built using Kuali Rice, Spring, Struts, OJB, JSP and Javascript. On the project I was a software developer responsible for implementing new features from specifications and other general development.

As a Systems Programmer Sr. I was the senior developer on the team responsible for providing services to students that ranged from computer labs, residential network access, to technology support such as Mysql and Subversion. I had the opportunity and freedom to help improve the teams processes through new development, such as designing and implementing new tools that fully automated the process of configuring computers after they were imaged, saving my team hundreds of hours each semester when the computer labs were being updated. I championed and implemented campus access to services such as Mysql and Subversion giving staff and students access to tools that the central IT department already used to build projects. I started a code and security review process on my team that was expanded to include projects across campus and built coding standards that were shared and incorporated into groups around campus. I envisioned and helped design a technical method for automated processing of copyright complaints on campus saving hours of time each week to locate, identify and process each complaint.
recommendations: Lanita Collette
Chief Information Security Officer at University of Arizona
February 17, 2014, Lanita managed Douglas directly

I had the distinct pleasure of working with Doug here at Northern Arizona University. The Student Computing and Networking team provided programming and system administration for a wide range of student computing needs. Doug's outstanding technical and leadership skills were instrumental in the success of the team's projects. He was dedicated to serving the student's needs, found creative and efficient solutions for a variety of services, and was always my go-to person when difficult technical problems arose. I highly recommend Doug for any hands-on technical leadership position where innovation and hard work are needed.

John Campbell
Peace Corps Volunteer, Dornod Institute, Mongolia
February 15, 2014, John was senior to Douglas but didn’t manage directly

It was my privilege, as Academic Computing Director at Northern Arizona University, to help recruit Doug from his Computer Science degree program to work in my department before he had actually graduated from school. This effort paid off hugely for an organization that did not have a big salary budget. Doug was already an extremely strong C++ programmer before he graduated and became, from 2001 - 2009, one of our strongest and most versatile Windows, unix, and web developers. He championed major improvements in code peer review and code management tools, especially in our emerging Java environments. He also found open-source solutions to a number of problem areas and his solutions survived well beyond his time in my organization. In fact, as he was leaving NAU, we collaborated with another author to publishing an article called "Why Central IT Must Embrace Open Source" based on one of his departmental reports. He remains one of the strongest developers that I have known and is truly a joy to work with.John Campbell, Ed.D.Former Director of Academic ComputingRecently Returned Peace Corps Volunteer from Mongolia
